content.description:
Jug through the first bolt, then climb a technical and engaging dihedral to a funky roof.

The old guidebook calls this a 5.11+ toprope. Looks like it got bolts at some point. The first 10 feet are blanker than blank, unless I missed something.
If you walked up the sandy approach trail, this route will be just on your right.  The first half is lie backing up a slab.  The crack turns verticle at half way point, this is were the crux is.
content.protection: Gear to 2".  Chains at the top.
content.location: This is to the east of the alcove area's and to the west of the sun wall

content.description: Start in a wide slot with a block that creates two finger cracks.  Awkward moves and insecure finger jams/liebacking will get you onto a ramp (and a much needed rest).  Continue up the dihedral to the anchors.  Gear from here is pretty much nonexistent.
content.protection: Micros to 1" will do.  Bolted anchors at the top.  Most people climb the Perfect Lieback then walk up around to TR this rig.
content.location: Up and left of P.L.  The start is atop a very large boulder.

content.description:
Climb a wide crack down low, transition right across a face, and gain another widening crack up high.

According to the old Anderson guide, this route used to have 3 fixed pins, but now it only appears to have one. Small cams (think black Alien, purple/silver TCU) protect what are probably the old pin scars in a left-slanting seam. The R comes from the fact that these placements are a bit hard to see, and if you blow them, it could be ugly.

All in all, an exciting and interesting route with a bit of spice.
content.location: Far left side of the Liebacks area, just before the High Caliber Corridor. Â Look for the obvious widening crack.
